<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_remove:
```c
int32 OS_remove(const char *path)
{
    int32 return_code;
    char  local_path[OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN];

    return_code = OS_TranslatePath(path, local_path);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_FileRemove_Impl(local_path);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
return_code = OS_TranslatePath(path, local_path);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: OS_TranslatePath(local_path) could copy/concatenate the translated path into local_path using unbounded string.h functions (e.g. strcpy/memcpy/strcat) without checking the destination size. If the translated path length >= OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN this will write beyond local_path, violating the rule. The call also lacks an explicit destination-size parameter, so unless OS_TranslatePath internally enforces bounds (e.g. uses strncpy/strncpy_s/strlcpy/snprintf with OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN and checks truncation) the use is potentially unsafe.
